sections.subtitle: Translate investing concepts into a diversified, goal-aligned portfolio

sections.title: What You'll Do
items: Define the purpose of your portfolio
Set target allocations for each asset class
Create a rebalancing routine to stay on track

sections.title: Start with Your Objective
sections.content: Your portfolio is a tool. Clarify what it should accomplish—long-term retirement income, a home down payment, or financial independence. Goals determine time horizon, risk level, and the mix of growth versus stability assets.

sections.title: Core and Satellite Approach
sections.content: The core holds broad-market index funds that deliver market returns at low cost. Satellite positions let you express preferences—like small-cap stocks, international exposure, or thematic ETFs. Cores keep you diversified, while satellites add potential outperformance without dominating results.

points.title: Age-Based Rule of Thumb
points.description: Subtract your age from 110 to estimate the stock percentage, adjusting for personal risk tolerance.

points.title: Goal Buckets
points.description: Assign separate portfolios to short-, medium-, and long-term goals so each can use the right risk level.

points.title: Expense Discipline
points.description: Keep weighted average expense ratios below 0.25% for most passive portfolios.

sections.title: Rebalancing Works
sections.content: Annual rebalancing across a 60/40 stock-bond portfolio added roughly 0.3% per year historically by forcing buy-low, sell-high discipline.

sections.title: Portfolio Build Workshop
steps: Write a sentence that defines your primary investment goal and time horizon.
List candidate funds or ETFs for the core portion (broad US equity, international equity, investment-grade bonds).
Choose up to three satellite ideas and cap each at 10% of the portfolio.
Assign target percentages to every holding and ensure the total equals 100%.
Schedule two rebalancing dates per year and note the trigger tolerance (e.g., +/- 5%).

sections.title: Document Your IPS
sections.content: Create a one-page investment policy statement (IPS) that records your allocations, contribution schedule, and rules for changing strategy. This keeps decisions rational when markets heat up or crash.
